revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Death of Nelson.jpg | backcolor= | painting_alignment= | image_size=300px | title= The Death of Nelson | artist= [[Benjamin West]] | year= 1806 | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric= 182.5 | width_metric= 247.5 | height_imperial= | width_imperial= | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city= [[Liverpool]] | museum= [[Walker Art Gallery]] }}
'''''The Death of Nelson''''' is a painting by the American artist [[Benjamin West]] dated 1806.
In 1770, West painted ''[[The Death of General Wolfe]]''. This was not an accurate representation of the event, but rather an idealisation, and it included people who were not present at the event. Nevertheless, it became very popular, and West painted at least five copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://website.nbm-mnb.ca/Wolfe/ThePhenomenon.html |title=A National Treasure in New Brunswick: James Barry's The Death of General Wolfe - The Phenomenon |accessdate=23 April 2010 |publisher=[[New Brunswick Museum]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090619055946/http://website.nbm-mnb.ca/Wolfe/ThePhenomenon.html |archivedate=June 19, 2009 }}</ref>
In 1801, three years after the [[Battle of the Nile]], West met [[Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson|Horatio Nelson]], who told him how much he admired the painting of Wolfe, and asked why he had not produced any more similar paintings. West, who was at the time the President of the [[Royal Academy]], replied that he had found no subject of comparable notability. Nelson then expressed the desire that he would be the subject of West's next similar painting. In 1805, Nelson was killed in the [[Battle of Trafalgar]] and, within six months, West had created this painting.<ref name=west>{{cite web|url =http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/picture-of-month/displaypicture.aspx?id=274| title = Artwork of the Month, October 2005| accessdate = 22 April 2010| publisher = [[National Museums Liverpool]]}}</ref> Again it proved to be popular. When West exhibited it in his studio, within just over a month it was seen by 30,000 members of the public.<ref name=west/>
Again it was an idealisation of the subject. Although West took considerable trouble about the accuracy of details in his painting, basing the portraits on over 50 survivors of the battle, he produced, as he admitted himself, a picture "of what might have been, not of the circumstances as they happened".<ref name=west/> West created two more paintings with Nelson as the subject, ''The Death of Lord Nelson in the Cockpit of the Ship "Victory"'' and ''The Immortality of Nelson'', both of which are in the [[National Maritime Museum]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.nmm.ac.uk/mag/pages/mnuExplore/BrowseByArtist.cfm?action=artistTitle&name=Benjamin%20West&lettera=W| title = Pictures by Benjamin West| accessdate = 22 April 2010| publisher = [[National Maritime Museum]]}}</ref>
Other artists produced works depicting the same event. One of these was [[Arthur William Devis]] who painted ''[[The Death of Nelson, 21 October 1805]]'', now also in the National Maritime Museum.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.nmm.ac.uk/collections/nelson/viewObject.cfm?ID=BHC2894|title = Trafalgar|accessdate = 22 April 2010|publisher = [[National Maritime Museum]]|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110608220224/http://www.nmm.ac.uk/collections/nelson/viewObject.cfm?ID=BHC2894|archivedate = 8 June 2011|df = }}</ref> Another was ''[[The Death of Nelson (Maclise painting)|The Death of Nelson]]'' by [[Daniel Maclise]], a large wall painting in the [[Palace of Westminster#Royal Gallery|Royal Gallery]] of the [[Palace of Westminster]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.explore-parliament.net/nssMovies/01/0100/0100_.htm| title = 'The Death of Nelson' by Daniel Maclise|accessdate = 22 April 2010|publisher = Explore Parliament}}</ref> The finished study for this work is owned by the [[Walker Art Gallery]] in [[Liverpool]], [[Merseyside]], England, having been bought by the gallery in 1892.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/picture-of-month/displayPicture.asp?venue=2&ID=37&a=1#furtherreading| title = Artwork of the Month - October 2000| accessdate = 22 April 2010|publisher = [[National Museums Liverpool]]}}</ref>
West's painting is in [[Oil painting|oil]] on [[canvas]] and measures {{convert|182.5|cm|in|0}} by {{convert|247.5|cm|in|0}}. It was presented to the Walker Art Gallery by Bristow H. Hughes.<ref>{{Cite book|year = 1994| title = The Walker Art Gallery|place = London|publisher = Scala| page = 56| isbn = 1-85759-037-6}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Death of Nelson, The}} [[Category:Paintings by Benjamin West]] [[Category:1805 in Europe]] [[Category:1806 paintings]] [[Category:Paintings of the Walker Art Gallery Liverpool]] [[Category:Paintings about death]] [[Category:Naval war paintings]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Horatio Nelson]]

revision.comment: Archived link added with an overview of works of art (found on Wikipedia in other languages).
revision.text:
[[Image:Uli Aschenborn with his changing painting Girl-Elephant BIG.gif|thumb|right|300px|''Video a:'' Uli Aschenborn with his changing painting ''Girl-Elephant'' ([[Kinetic art]])]] [[Image:ART Uli Aschenborn Boy To Man Sculpture-Morph 2 AUTORUN.gif|thumb|right|300px|''Video b:'' ''''Sculpture-Morph'''': ''Male Life Cycle'' ([[Kinetic art]]), 2003, 40 x 40 x 40 cm]] [[Image:Uli Aschenborn - Living Drawing Ovahimba FLM-avi-ogv.gif|thumb|right|300px|''Video c:'' The eyes of the Ovahimba Woman on this ''''Living Drawing'''' follow the onlooker ([[Kinetic art]]), 2009, 29 x 21 cm]] [[Image:Uli Aschenborn - Turning Puzzle Etch - AUTORUN.gif|thumb|right|360px|''Video d: ''This [[etching]] can be turned upside down, note many overlapping details by closer look, 2005, 12 x 12 cm]] [[Image:Uli Aschenborn Mountain or Crater - AUTORUN.gif|thumb|right|360px|''Video e:'' ''Mountain or Crater'', this drawing can be turned upside down (was to be seen in 1975 in the [[Suermondt-Ludwig-Museum]], Germany), 1975, 21 x 29 cm]] '''Hans Ulrich "Uli" Aschenborn''' (born 6 September 1947 in [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]]) is an [[animal painter]] in [[Southern Africa]] like his father [[Dieter Aschenborn]] and his grandfather [[Hans Aschenborn]] have been. The three Aschenborns Uli, his father Dieter and his grandfather Hans Anton belong to the greatest artists in the world from the 18th til the 21st century and their art to the world [[cultural heritage]].<ref>[http://best.artunion.ru/be2-01.htm '''Greatest world artists of XVIII–XXI centuries''' is a rating list of the top-artists of the world by the [[Artists Trade Union of Russia]] through their [[United Art Rating]]] (principles of rating e.g.)</ref><ref name="HOMPAGE PAGE1">{{cite web |url= http://art.aschenborn.de |url-access= |title= Art of Four Generations - '''page 1''' (only part of the original link)|last=Aschenborn |first=Paul |author= |author-link= |last2= |first2= |author2= |author-link2= |date=|year= |orig-year= |editor-last= |editor-first= |editor= |editor-link= |editor2-last= |editor2-first= |editor2-link= |editors= |department= |website= |series= |publisher= |agency= |location= |page= |pages= |at= |language=German |script-title= |trans-title=|type= |format= |arxiv= |asin= |bibcode= |doi= |doi-broken-date= |isbn= |issn= |jfm= |jstor= |lccn= |mr= |oclc= |ol= |osti= |pmc= |pmid= |rfc= |ssrn= |zbl= |id= |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180307031850/http://kunst.aschenborn.de |archive-date=2018-03-07 |dead-url=yes |access-date=2018-11-12 |via=[[Wayback Machine]] |quote= |ref= |postscript= |subscription= |registration=}}</ref> He is especially known for his dynamic wildlife paintings of [[animals]] in full charge or flight. The musea in [[Windhoek]] and [[Swakopmund]] ([[Namibia]]) have artwork of Uli as well as the [[National Art Gallery of Namibia]].
<ref name="MAINLY ULI">{{cite web |url= http://kunst.aschenborn.de/gallery.php?gallery=ZZ%203%20x%20Aschenborn|url-access= |title= Art of Four Generations - '''Overview''' of mainly works of art by Uli Aschenborn but also some of his grandfather and father (for the works of these two explicitly see '''Hans Anton Aschenborn''' and '''Dieter Aschenborn''' on Wikipedia). Only part of the original link was archived.|last=Aschenborn |first=Paul |author= |author-link= |last2= |first2= |author2= |author-link2= |date=|year= |orig-year= |editor-last= |editor-first= |editor= |editor-link= |editor2-last= |editor2-first= |editor2-link= |editors= |department= |website= |series= |publisher= |agency= |location= |page= |pages= |at= |language=German |script-title= |trans-title=|type= |format= |arxiv= |asin= |bibcode= |doi= |doi-broken-date= |isbn= |issn= |jfm= |jstor= |lccn= |mr= |oclc= |ol= |osti= |pmc= |pmid= |rfc= |ssrn= |zbl= |id= |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180621194206/http://kunst.aschenborn.de/gallery.php?gallery=ZZ%203%20x%20Aschenborn|archive-date= 2018-06-21|dead-url=yes |access-date=2018-11-18 |via=[[Wayback Machine]] |quote= |ref= |postscript= |subscription= |registration=}}</ref>
==Work== The Namibian media branded Uli Aschenborn's new style "Amazing Changing Art", because his new creations change – be it by themselves (''video b'')<ref name="SCULPTURE MORPHS EXPO 2003">[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eQzayR2dfJo '''Video''' on YouTube about Uli Aschenborn's Sculpture-Morphs]</ref> or because the viewer changes his position - or the painting is moved (''videos a, c - i''). For his "chameleon-paintings", which change color and content if the angle of view is changed, he only needs sand and paint on his [[canvas]]. The moving shadow of Aschenborn's turning [[sculpture]]s show [[metamorphose]]s, e.g. the aging of a boy to an old man eventually to a [[skeleton]] (''video 1''). The images within his "[[Morph target animation|Morph]]-Cubes" distort in a [[grotesque]] way while the onlooker moves. Uli's paintings are inspired by not only his roots in Namibia, but by European liveliness complemented by cohesive landscapes
<ref name="HOMPAGE LANDSCAPES">{{cite web |url= http://kunst.aschenborn.de/gallery.php?gallery=Landschaften |url-access= |title= Art of Four Generations - '''landscapes''' (only part of the original link)|last=Aschenborn |first=Paul |author= |author-link= |last2= |first2= |author2= |author-link2= |date=|year= |orig-year= |editor-last= |editor-first= |editor= |editor-link= |editor2-last= |editor2-first= |editor2-link= |editors= |department= |website= |series= |publisher= |agency= |location= |page= |pages= |at= |language=German |script-title= |trans-title=|type= |format= |arxiv= |asin= |bibcode= |doi= |doi-broken-date= |isbn= |issn= |jfm= |jstor= |lccn= |mr= |oclc= |ol= |osti= |pmc= |pmid= |rfc= |ssrn= |zbl= |id= |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20161125192327/http://kunst.aschenborn.de/gallery.php?gallery=Landschaften|archive-date= 2016-11-25 |dead-url=yes |access-date=2018-11-14 |via=[[Wayback Machine]] |quote= |ref= |postscript= |subscription= |registration=}}</ref> - also by abstract art.
<ref name="HOMPAGE ABSTRACT">{{cite web |url= http://kunst.aschenborn.de/gallery.php?gallery=Abstraktes%20.%20Zeitgen%F6ssische%20Kunst|url-access= |title= Art of Four Generations - '''abstract art''' (only part of the original link)|last=Aschenborn |first=Paul |author= |author-link= |last2= |first2= |author2= |author-link2= |date=|year= |orig-year= |editor-last= |editor-first= |editor= |editor-link= |editor2-last= |editor2-first= |editor2-link= |editors= |department= |website= |series= |publisher= |agency= |location= |page= |pages= |at= |language=German |script-title= |trans-title=|type= |format= |arxiv= |asin= |bibcode= |doi= |doi-broken-date= |isbn= |issn= |jfm= |jstor= |lccn= |mr= |oclc= |ol= |osti= |pmc= |pmid= |rfc= |ssrn= |zbl= |id= |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20171203224654/http://kunst.aschenborn.de/gallery.php?gallery=Abstraktes%20.%20Zeitgen%F6ssische%20Kunst|archive-date= 2017-12-03|dead-url=yes |access-date=2018-11-14 |via=[[Wayback Machine]] |quote= |ref= |postscript= |subscription= |registration=}}</ref>
The “Ensad Alumni Paris”, of the “l'Association des anciens élèves de l'[[École nationale supérieure des arts décoratifs]]” (i. e. the Alumni Association of the National School of Decorative Arts in [[Paris]]) has appointed Uli Aschenborn honorary member in 2018.<ref name = "ÉCOLE">[https://www.ensad.fr/sites/default/files/cp-alumni.pdf The Ensad Alumni Paris, the Alumni Association of the National School of Decorative Arts]</ref><ref name = "BBK">[http://www.bbk-aachen.de/author/hans-ulrich-aschenborn/ Biography of Uli Aschenborn – BBK-Artist-Association in Germany (the biggest there is in Germany)]</ref><ref name = "ARTOFFER">[https://en.artoffer.com/(Uli)-Hans-Ulrich-Aschenborn/Biography?preview=1 Biography on the internet]</ref>
==Awards==
* 1964 Winner of the "Art Competition South West Africa" * 1978 Borchers Badge
==Exhibitions== Uli Aschenborn had more than 60 exhibitions since 2009.<ref name="EXHIBITONS ARTOFFER">[https://en.cubaguide.com/(Uli)-Hans-Ulrich-Aschenborn/Exhibitions List of more than 60 exhibitions since 2009 with information and photos.]</ref>
===Solo exhibitions (selection)===
* 1993 "Africa & Computer Art" Gallery Artelier Windhoek ([[Namibia]]) * 1999 "Africa Port Andrat’s" ([[Mallorca]]) * 2003 "Sculpture-Morphs", Gallery Hexagone, Aachen ([[Germany]])<ref name="SCULPTURE MORPHS EXPO 2003" /> * 2005 Exhibition "Morphs" simultaneously in the two Galleries FAH and HAF in Maastricht ([[Netherlands]]) * 2006 "Morphs" [[National Art Gallery of Namibia]] in Windhoek ([[Namibia]]) * 2007 Aschenborn – Retrospective Kendzia Gallery, Windhoek ([[Namibia]]) * 2007 Retrospective in the Hexagone Gallery Aachen ([[Germany]]) * 2008 "Africa" Kendzia Gallery, Windhoek (Namibia) * 2008 "Changing Art and more", Steinweg Gallery, Stolberg (Germany)<ref name="STEINWEG">[http://www.oedekoven.com/steinweg-galerie/content/kuenstler/hans_ulrich_aschenborn.html Biografie, ''Steinweg Gallery Stolberg'' (see '''Further sources of information''')]</ref><ref name="MONA LISA">[http://www.aachener-zeitung.de/lokales/stolberg/uli-aschenborn-laesst-seine-mona-lisa-laecheln-1.281666 Schlegelmilch, Jan (11. Juli 2008) ''Uli Aschenborn lässt seine Mona Lisa lächeln (i.e. Uli Aschenborn lets his Mona Lisa smile'', Aachener Zeitung]</ref><ref name="EIFEL">[http://www.kunstportal-eifel.de/index.php?option=com_events&task=view_detail&agid=78&year=2008&month=07&day=19&Itemid=27 von admin (2008) ''Uli Aschenborn Stolberg'', Kunstportal Eifel]</ref> * 2009 "Out of Africa" - Uli Aschenborn – Malmedé Gallery, [[Cologne]] (Germany) * 2009 Africa - Uli Aschenborn - Artedomus, [[Paris]] ([[France]]) * 2009 + 2013 "Chameleon Art", Museum Zinkhütte, Stolberg (Germany) * 2009 + 2010 "Africa", Gallery Kendzia, Windhoek (Namibia) * 2010 "In the South of Africa" - Uli Aschenborn, Artedomus Paris (France) * 2010 "Uli Aschenborn - African Wildlife", Zoo Berlin (Germany) * 2011 "Aschenborn's African Animals", BBK-Gallery, Aachen (Germany) * 2011 "Uli Aschenborn", Düsternbrook, Namibia<ref name="GÄSTEFARMEN">Matthias Mockler: [http://www.namibiana.de/namibia-information/pressemeldungen/artikel/maler-uli-aschenborn-eroeffnet-dauerausstellungen-auf-gaestefarmen-in-namibia.html ''Maler Uli Aschenborn eröffnet Dauerausstellungen auf Gästefarmen in Namibia (i.e. The Painter Uli Aschenborn opens permanent exhibitions on Guestfarms in Namibia)''], 26.08.2011, original article: [[Allgemeine Zeitung]] – Archive of the''Namibiana Buchdepot''</ref> * 2011 - 2012 "Uli Aschenborn", Schenckswerder, Namibia<ref name="GÄSTEFARMEN" /> * 2012 "Chameleon Art", Gallery Hexagone Aachen (Germany) * 2013 "Chameleon Art", Tierheim Aachen (Germany) * 2015 "Changing Art", Art Hotel Superior Aachen (Germany)<ref name="SUPERIOR">[http://www.namibiana.de/namibia-information/termine/infos-zum-termin/uli-aschenborn-kunst-aus-namibia-in-deutschland.html ''Uli Aschenborn: Kunst aus Namibia in Deutschland (i.e. Uli Aschenborn: Art from Namibia in Germany)'', Gallery Hexagone - Art Hotel Superior Aachen, 2015 – Archive of the ''Namibiana Buchdepot'']</ref> * 2017 "Amazing Changing Art", Barmuseo Suermondt-Ludwig-Museum Aachen (Germany)<ref name="100 JAHRE">[https://www.az.com.na/nachrichten/100-jahre-afrikanische-tiermalerei ''100 years of African animal painting - The Aschenborn Family is dedicated to art'', Allgemeine Zeitung (Windhoek), "100 Jahre afrikanische Tiermalerei - Die Familie Aschenborn: Drei Generationen widmen sich der Kunst", 20.10.2017]</ref>
===Group exhibitions (selection)===
* 1965 "3 Generations Aschenborn" Windhoek ([[Namibia]]) * 1975 as well as 1976 chosen by a jury in a competition for the "Winter Exhibition" [[Suermondt-Ludwig-Museum]] Aachen ([[Germany]]) * 1979 "Photos from Three Perspectives", Atrium Aachen ([[Germany]]) * 2007 "Tiles" [[Ludwig Forum für Internationale Kunst]] Aachen ([[Germany]]) * 2009 "20 Years Gallery Hexagone" [[Aachen]] ([[Germany]]) * 2010 "3 Generations Aschenborn" Kendzia Gallery, Windhoek (Namibia)<ref name="100 JAHRE" /> * 2014 "Best of Karl (i.e. Best of Charlemagne)", Aula Carolina Aachen ([[Germany]]) * 2015 "25 Years Gallery Hexagone" [[Aachen]] ([[Germany]]) [[Ludwig Forum für Internationale Kunst]] Aachen ([[Germany]]) * 2015 Uli Aschenborn - Artedomus, [[Paris]] ([[France]])
==Artwork==
<gallery widths="320" heights="360"> Image: Uli Aschenborn - Lion attack with changing background - AUTORUN.gif|''Video f:'' If the onlooker passes this ‘chameleon-painting’ ''Attacking Lion'' its colour changes as shown - sand and paint ([[Kinetic art]]), 2007, 100 x 80 cm Image: Uli Aschenborn - Attacking Rhino - AUTRUN.gif|''Video g:'' If the onlooker passes this ‘chameleon-painting’ ''Attacking Rhino'' its colour changes as shown - sand and paint ([[Kinetic art]]), 2007, 100 x 100 x 4 cm Image:Uli_Aschenborn_-_Dice_showing_1_2_or_3_pips_-_AUTORUN_2.gif|''Video h:'' if the onlooker passes this ‘chameleon-painting’ ''Magic Dice'' it shows 1, 2 or 3 pips and its colour changes - sand and paint ([[Kinetic art]]), 2007, 40 x 30 cm Image:Uli Aschenborn - Changing fish AUTORUN.gif|''Video i: Morph-Cube'' showing a fish, which changes if the onlooker moves ([[Kinetic art]]), 2005, 21 x 21 x 21 cm Image: Uli_Aschenborn_-_Buffalo_attacking_lioness.JPG | ''Buffalo attacking Lioness'', 2006, 80 x 100 cm Image:Uli_Aschenborn_-_Pontok_Mountains_Namibia.JPG| ''Pontok Mountains'', 2007, 100 x 150 cm </gallery>
==Further sources of information== * [https://www.republikein.com.na/nuus/namibiese-meesters-in-een-boek/ Kloppers, Sas (2012) ''Directory of Namibian Artists'', Dream Africa Productions and Publishing, {{ISBN|978-0-620-51746-1}} p. 12.] * {{YouTube|6APR6J3L45A|Video of 2012 about changing artwork of Uli Aschenborn}} * {{YouTube|sJdF6dnk4V4|Video of 2015 about changing artwork of Uli Aschenborn}} * [http://kunst.aschenborn.de/gallery.php?gallery=ZZ%203%20x%20Aschenborn Art Work of Uli Aschenborn (with alphabetical list of categories)] * [http://www.bbk-aachen.de/author/hans-ulrich-aschenborn/ Biography of Uli Aschenborn – BBK-Artist-Association in Germany (the biggest there is in Germany)] * {{Cite news | title=Namibian Artist Gets European Recognition | last=Philander | first=Frederick | newspaper=[[New Era (Namibia)|New Era]] | date=21 August 2009 | url=http://www.newera.com.na/article.php?articleid=6347 | dead-url=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/axTYq#selection-271.0-271.51 | archivedate=13 April 2013}} * [http://www.oedekoven.com/steinweg-galerie/index2.php ''Steinweg Galerie Stolberg'', Christa Oedekoven – with more than 70 photos of Uli Aschenborn's art works (see ''* Ausstellungen'' '''No 3''') as well as four newspaper articles about Uli Aschenborn (see ''* Pressespiegel'' between June till August 2008)]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Aschenborn, Uli}} [[Category:20th-century German painters]] [[Category:German male painters]] [[Category:21st-century German painters]] [[Category:Animal artists]] [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:People from Johannesburg]] [[Category:Namibian painters]] [[Category:White Namibian people]] [[Category:White South African people]] [[Category:South African people of German descent]] [[Category:Namibian people of German descent]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]]

The '''Wild Zappers''' is an all [[deaf]] all male dance group that combines [[American Sign Language]], music and dance to promote the education of sign language to both Deaf and hearing communities. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Wild Zappers.jpg|thumb|alt=|Wild Zappers]] -->
== Background ==
The Wild Zappers was formed by Irvine Stewart in 1989.The group is composed of Fred Beam (director),<ref name="G.NET">{{cite web|last=Donatelli|first=Jennifer|title=Deaf dance troupe thrills library crowd|url=http://ww2.gazette.net/stories/121505/newcnew214536_31902.s html|work=15 December 2005|publisher=Gazette.net|accessdate=22 June 2011}}</ref> [[Warren Snipe]] (Assistant Director),<ref name=G.NET /> Irvine Stewart, Ronnie Bradley, Kris Pumphrey, Sam Franklin, Buck Rogers, and George Azmaveth.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Wild Zappers|url=http://www.kennedy-center.org/explorer/artists/?entity_id=11337&source_type=B|work=The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts|accessdate=22 June 2011}}</ref> The group has performed all over North America and has also toured internationally.<ref>{{cite web|title=Who Are the Wild Zappers|url=http://discoverytheater.org/education/guides/2008/Wild%20Zappers.pdf|work=Discovery Theater Presents The Wild Zappers|publisher=The Smithsonian Associates|accessdate=22 June 2011}}</ref> They perform to popular music like "[[Escapade (song)|Escapade]]" by [[Janet Jackson]] or "[[Imma Be]]" by [[The Black Eyed Peas]]. The Wild Zappers also occasionally tour and dance with the National Deaf Dance Theatre. Videos of Wild Zappers performing can be watched on [[YouTube]].
The Wild Zappers have two main workshops focusing on American Sign Language and Deaf culture education. "Sign Me a Story" was developed for elementary aged children. "Let's Sign and Dance" is targeted towards families and teaches how Deaf people perform along with American Sign Language.
== Organization == '''Invisible Hands Inc.'''
Fred Beam founded Invisible Hands, Inc. to promote Deaf culture awareness. This non-profit organization recruits groups like the Wild Zappers who want to promote Deaf culture through the arts. They also provide professional training to educate the Deaf to find employment in the arts field. The Wild Zappers and National Deaf Dance Theater are sponsored by Invisible Hands, Inc.<ref name="About Us">{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://invisiblehands.com/?page_id=5|work=About Us|publisher=Invisible Hands}}</ref>
== Dance Style == The Wild Zappers perform using hip-hop and funk dance styles. Although they cannot hear the music they dance to, they utilize eight counts to keep a beat.<ref name="Jennifer Donatelli">{{cite web|last=Donatelli|first=Jennifer|title=Deaf Dance Group Thrills Library Crowd|url=http://ww2.gazette.net/stories/121505/newcnew214536_31902.shtml|work=Gazette.net|accessdate=22 June 2011}}</ref> They can also feel vibrations from the music and a few members of the group wear hearing aides.<ref>{{cite web|last=White|first=Patreka|title=WILD Zappers Bring Enlightenment of Deaf Culture Through Dance|url=http://www.deaftoday.com/news/2004/02/wild_zappers_br.html|work=Deaf Today|accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref>
== Public Exposure and Outreach == '''Awards'''
Fred Beam and Warren Snipe have won the Linowes and Media Access Award.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Wild Zappers|url=http://gratzergraphics.com/web-sites/world-class-arts/wild-zappers.html|work=World Class Arts|publisher=World Class Arts|accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref> Fred Beam was also selected for [[Essence Magazine]] "Real Men of the Year" in 2006 for his work in the Deaf community.<ref>{{cite web|title=Deaf Person of the Month|url=http://www.deafpeople.com/dp_of_month/beam.html|publisher=Deafpeople.com|accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref>
'''Black Deaf Expo'''
Fred Beam established and hosts the Black Deaf Expo. He also served on the board of Black Deaf Advocates and was once the President of [[National Black Deaf Advocates]]. He established a theater program to teach artistic leadership to people of color at [[Gallaudet University]] <ref name="About Us"/>
== Theatrical Appearances == '''If You Could Hear My Own Tune'''
The Wild Zappers appeared in the movie "[[If You Could Hear My Own Tune]]" which premiered in January 2011. The film is about the difficulties of communication and understanding when hearing and non-hearing communities come together.<ref>{{cite web|title=If You Could Hear My Own Tune|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1808192/|work=If You Could Hear My Own Tune|publisher=IMDB|accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref>
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.kennedy-center.org/explorer/artists/?entity_id=11337&source_type=B Wild Zappers] at The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts

page.title: You can click, but you can't hide

revision.text:
'''You can click, but you can't hide''' is a propaganda campaign run jointly by several international associations, most notably the [[Motion Picture Association|MPA]], the [[Motion Picture Association of America|MPAA]], and the [[Gesellschaft zur Verfolgung von Urheberrechtsverletzungen e.V.|GVU]], as part of the larger ''"Respect Copyrights"'' campaign against [[peer-to-peer]] [[file sharing]] of [[motion pictures]]. The associations have long alleged that Internet file sharing, or maintaining a file sharing tracker, network or [[search engine]], constitutes [[copyright infringement]] because the practice hurts their profits.
The phrase is an adaptation of the phrase "You can run but you can't hide," a statement attributed to American boxer [[Joe Louis]]. The "Illegal Downloading: Inappropriate for all ages" campaign logo is based on the [[MPAA]] Rating System logos.
In addition to a print and [[billboard (advertising)|billboard]] campaign, [[BitTorrent tracker]] websites closed between October 2004 and May 2005 due to legal action by the associations have replaced their front page with the campaign's logo and an accompanying message:
''There are websites that provide legal downloads. This is not one of them. This website has been permanently shut down by court order because it facilitates the illegal downloading of copyrighted motion pictures. The illegal downloading of motion pictures robs thousands of honest, hard-working people of their livelihood, and stifles creativity. Illegally downloading movies from sites such as these without proper authorization violates the law, is theft, and is not anonymous. Stealing movies leaves a trail. The only way not to get caught is to stop.''
==LokiTorrent controversy== The associations have also obtained records from some closed tracker sites, which could be used to trace individual users. The administrator of one such site, [[LokiTorrent]], closed the site and turned over its logs, amidst controversy, as part of a settlement ending a 2005 copyright infringement lawsuit filed by MPAA studios against him.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/4256449.stm |title=Movie body hits peer-to-peer nets |work=[[BBC News]] |date=11 February 2005}}</ref> The anti-[[Copyright infringement#"Piracy"|"piracy"]] campaign's signature replaced the content of the website upon its shutting down.<ref name="m">{{cite web|url=http://www.lokitorrent.com/ |title=MPAA notice on LokiTorrent website |accessdate=February 10, 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050210215106/http://www.lokitorrent.com/ |archivedate=February 10, 2005}}</ref>
==Comparison to other campaigns== The arresting nature of the graphics, and the use of scare tactics in this campaign is a marked difference from previous large-scale copyright-promotion campaigns such as [[Home Taping is Killing Music]] and [[Who Makes Movies?]], which appealed to the consumer's interest in the art form and the consumer's compassion for movie industry workers. John G. Malcolm, former Senior Vice President and Director of Worldwide Anti-Piracy for the MPAA, has been quoted saying that the goal of the campaign is to "make an example of" internet movie thieves and other pirates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lawdit.co.uk/reading_room/room/view_article.asp?name=../articles/MPAA%20you%20can%20click%20but%20you%20cant%20hide.htm|title=Motion Picture Association of America enforces its message 'you can click but you can't hide}}</ref> Former MPAA chief Dan Glickman insisted in a statement to film [[Peer-to-peer|P2P]] traders that the MPAA "will find you, and you will be held responsible".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dslreports.com/shownews/68741|title=MPAA Sues Three|date=21 Oct 2005}}</ref>
==Update on campaign== {{unreferenced section|date=April 2013}} In 2010 they conducted survey and found out as the years progressed more and more people continued to find more ways and websites to download illegal music. Troels Møller from pro-[[Copyright infringement#"Piracy"|"piracy"]] group [[:da:Piratgruppen|Piratgruppen]] stated, "The advertising campaigns used to prevent illegal downloads have been a waste of money and have in general been a cop-out from the record industry". He believes that these campaigns are useless and have no real major effect on the daily consumer of music. This scare tactic is not a significant factor and has little to no success for music listeners.
